title: Concept of Sampling

choices.text: Taking large samples that are nearly the same size as the population.
Taking a sample in hopes that it will give the statistician a snapshot of how the population behaves or feels.
Taking only simple random samples, where everybody in the population has an equal chance of being selected.
Getting results from all subjects in the population.
Interviewing subjects that are easiest to reach, hoping to get as large of a sample as possible.

correct_answer: Choice 'A'is incorrect; in most situations, the sample is much smaller than the population, and if the sample is perfectly random, a sample size of 1,000âˆ’2,000 subjects is usually large enough.
solution:
Choice 'B' is correct; this is the basic definition of sampling.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; while simple random samples give good results, other types of samples such as multistage or stratified also work well in certain situations.

Choice 'D" is incorrect; this describes a census.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; this describes a convenience sample, which typically contains high amounts of bias.
